instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.P1V8S3_PGOOD: What is P1V8S3_PGOOD? P1V8S3_PGOOD is a signal that denotes that the PP1V8_S3 power rail is working..

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message:
someone has worked on this board before me.

board gets green then orange light with an original 85w charger. No fan spin :(

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.58
PPBUS S5 HS COMPUTING = 12.57
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 16.50
PP3V42 G3H = 3.428
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3-3.4v pulsing
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0.0-0.060v pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> = pulsing 0v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> = 0 - 0.3v pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0 - 3.3v pulsing

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 13.8ohm resistance to ground


<CHIP>U1900</CHIP> looks good but I've replaced this anyway.
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> looks good.
Smc looks good, glue is still there.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses too?

Is better to use o-scope to see if power rails and signals rise theyr nominal values.
A DC voltmeter is too "lazy" to capture very short pulses; eventualy shows smaller values than expected...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 38690"]<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses too?

Is better to use o-scope to see if power rails and signals rise theyr nominal values.
A DC voltmeter is too "lazy" to capture very short pulses; eventualy shows smaller values than expected...[/QUOTE]


no power on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> nor on PP1v8S3.


<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> show nothing on o-scope.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message:
Means <SIGNAL>P1V8S3_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is missing.
That's the reason <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> stays low.
Repair corresponding 1V8 power supply.
Check for short first...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: board is fixed. <CAPACITOR>C7518</CAPACITOR> was missing. previous repairman didn't put that back in :mad:

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - no power
threads.message: thanks [B][URL="https://www.rossmanngroup.com/boards/member/682-2informaticos"]2informaticos[/URL], [/B]you lead me to <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> power supply.
